00010 #if !defined(GEOGRAPHICLIB_LAMBERTCONFORMALCONIC_HPP)
00011 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_LAMBERTCONFORMALCONIC_HPP "$Id: LambertConformalConic.hpp 6898 2010-11-19 19:21:49Z karney $"

00013 #include "GeographicLib/Constants.hpp"

00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief Lambert Conformal Conic Projection
00020    *
00021    * Implementation taken from the report,
00022    * - J. P. Snyder,
00023    *   <a href="http://pubs.er.usgs.gov/usgspubs/pp/pp1395"> Map Projections: A
00024    *   Working Manual</a>, USGS Professional Paper 1395 (1987),
00025    *   pp. 107&ndash;109.
00026    *
00027    * This is a implementation of the equations in Snyder except that divided
00028    * differences have been used to transform the expressions into ones which
00029    * may be evaluated accurately and that Newton's method is used to invert the
00030    * projection.  In this implementation, the projection correctly becomes the
00031    * Mercator projection or the polar sterographic projection when the standard
00032    * latitude is the equator or a pole.  The accuracy of the projections is
00033    * about 10 nm.
00034    *
00035    * The ellipsoid parameters, the standard parallels, and the scale on the
00036    * standard parallels are set in the constructor.  Internally, the case with
00037    * two standard parallels is converted into a single standard parallel, the
00038    * latitude of tangency (also the latitude of minimum scale).  This latitude
00039    * is also used as the latitude of origin which is returned by
00040    * LambertConformalConic::OriginLatitude.  The scale on the latitude of
00041    * origin is given by LambertConformalConic::CentralScale.  The case with two
00042    * distinct standard parallels where one is a pole is singular and is
00043    * disallowed.  The central meridian (which is a trivial shift
00044    * of the longitude) is specified as the \e lon0 argument of the
00045    * LambertConformalConic::Forward and LambertConformalConic::Reverse
00046    * functions.  There is no provision in this class for specifying a false
00047    * easting or false northing or a different latitude of origin.  However
00048    * these are can be simply included by the calling function.  For example the
00049    * Pennsylvania South state coordinate system
00050    * (<a href="http://www.spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/3364/"> EPSG:3364</a>)
00051    * is obtained by:
00052    \code
00053    const double
00054      a = GeographicLib::Constants::WGS84_a(), r = 298.257222101, // GRS80
00055      lat1 = 39 + 56/60.0, lat1 = 40 + 58/60.0, // standard parallels
00056      k1 = 1,                                   // scale
00057      lat0 = 39 + 20/60.0, lon0 = 75 + 45/60.0, // origin
00058      fe = 600000, fn = 0;                      // false easting and northing
00059    // Set up basic projection
00060    const GeographicLib::LambertConformalConic PASouth(a, r, lat1, lat2, k1);
00061    double x0, y0;
00062    {
00063      // Transform origin point
00064      PASouth.Forward(lon0, lat0, lon0, x0, y0);
00065      x0 -= fe; y0 -= fn;         // Combine result with false origin
00066    }
00067    double lat, lon, x, y;
00068    // Sample conversion from geodetic to PASouth grid
00069    std::cin >> lat >> lon;
00070    PASouth.Forward(lon0, lat, lon, x, y);
00071    x -= x0; y -= y0;
00072    std::cout << x << " " << y << "\n";
00073    // Sample conversion from PASouth grid to geodetic
00074    std::cin >> x >> y;
00075    x += x0; y += y0;
00076    PASouth.Reverse(lon0, x, y, lat, lon);
00077    std::cout << lat << " " << lon << "\n";
00078    \endcode
00079    **********************************************************************/
00080   class LambertConformalConic {
00081   private:
00082     typedef Math::real real;
00083     const real _a, _r, _f, _fm, _e2, _e, _e2m;
00084     real _sign, _n, _nc, _t0nm1, _scale, _lat0, _k0;
00085     real _scbet0, _tchi0, _scchi0, _psi0, _nrho0;
00086     static const real eps, epsx, tol, ahypover;
00087     static const int numit = 5;
00088     static inline real sq(real x) throw() { return x * x; }
00089     static inline real hyp(real x) throw() { return Math::hypot(real(1), x); }
00090     // e * atanh(e * x) = log( ((1 + e*x)/(1 - e*x))^(e/2) ) if f >= 0
00091     // - sqrt(-e2) * atan( sqrt(-e2) * x)                    if f < 0
00092     inline real eatanhe(real x) const throw() {
00093       return _f >= 0 ? _e * Math::atanh(_e * x) : - _e * std::atan(_e * x);
00094     }
00095     // Divided differences
00096     // Definition: Df(x,y) = (f(x)-f(y))/(x-y)
00097     // See: W. M. Kahan and R. J. Fateman,
00098     // Symbolic computation of divided differences,
00099     // SIGSAM Bull. 33(3), 7-28 (1999)
00100     // http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/334714.334716
00101     // http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~fateman/papers/divdiff.pdf
00102     //
00103     // General rules
00104     // h(x) = f(g(x)): Dh(x,y) = Df(g(x),g(y))*Dg(x,y)
00105     // h(x) = f(x)*g(x):
00106     //        Dh(x,y) = Df(x,y)*(g(x)+g(y))/2 + Dg(x,y)*(f(x)+f(y))/2
00107     //
00108     // hyp(x) = sqrt(1+x^2): Dhyp(x,y) = (x+y)/(hyp(x)+hyp(y))
00109     static inline real Dhyp(real x, real y, real hx, real hy) throw()
00110     // hx = hyp(x)
00111     { return (x + y) / (hx + hy); }
00112     // sn(x) = x/sqrt(1+x^2): Dsn(x,y) = (x+y)/((sn(x)+sn(y))*(1+x^2)*(1+y^2))
00113     static inline real Dsn(real x, real y, real sx, real sy) throw() {
00114       // sx = x/hyp(x)
00115       real t = x * y;
00116       return t > 0 ? (x+y) * sq( (sx*sy)/t ) / (sx+sy) :
00117         (x-y != 0 ? (sx-sy) / (x-y) : 1);
00118     }
00119     // Dlog1p(x,y) = log1p((x-y)/(1+y)/(x-y)
00120     static inline real Dlog1p(real x, real y) throw() {
00121       real t = x - y; if (t < 0) { t = -t; y = x; }
00122       return t != 0 ? Math::log1p(t/(1+y)) / t : 1/(1+x);
00123     }
00124     // Dexp(x,y) = exp((x+y)/2) * 2*sinh((x-y)/2)/(x-y)
00125     static inline real Dexp(real x, real y) throw() {
00126       real t = (x - y)/2;
00127       return (t != 0 ? sinh(t)/t : real(1)) * exp((x + y)/2);
00128     }
00129     // Dsinh(x,y) = 2*sinh((x-y)/2)/(x-y) * cosh((x+y)/2)
00130     //   cosh((x+y)/2) = (c+sinh(x)*sinh(y)/c)/2
00131     //   c=sqrt((1+cosh(x))*(1+cosh(y)))
00132     //   cosh((x+y)/2) = sqrt( (sinh(x)*sinh(y) + cosh(x)*cosh(y) + 1)/2 )
00133     static inline real Dsinh(real x, real y, real sx, real sy, real cx, real cy)
00134       // sx = sinh(x), cx = cosh(x)
00135       throw() {
00136       // real t = (x  - y)/2, c = sqrt((1 + cx) * (1 + cy));
00137       // return (t != 0 ? sinh(t)/t : real(1)) * (c + sx * sy / c) /2;
00138       real t = (x  - y)/2;
00139       return (t != 0 ? sinh(t)/t : real(1)) * sqrt((sx * sy + cx * cy + 1) /2);
00140     }
00141     // Dasinh(x,y) = asinh((x-y)*(x+y)/(x*sqrt(1+y^2)+y*sqrt(1+x^2)))/(x-y)
00142     //             = asinh((x*sqrt(1+y^2)-y*sqrt(1+x^2)))/(x-y)
00143     static inline real Dasinh(real x, real y, real hx, real hy) throw() {
00144       // hx = hyp(x)
00145       real t = x - y;
00146       return t != 0 ?
00147         Math::asinh(x*y > 0 ? t * (x+y) / (x*hy + y*hx) : x*hy - y*hx) / t :
00148         1/hx;
00149     }
00150     // Deatanhe(x,y) = eatanhe((x-y)/(1-e^2*x*y))/(x-y)
00151     inline real Deatanhe(real x, real y) const throw() {
00152       real t = x - y, d = (1 - _e2 * x * y);
00153       return t != 0 ? eatanhe(t / d) / t : _e2 / d;
00154     }
00155     void Init(real sphi1, real cphi1, real sphi2, real cphi2, real k1) throw();
00156   public:
00157 
00158     /**
00159      * Constructor with a single standard parallel.
00160      *
00161      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00162      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00163      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00164      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00165      * @param[in] stdlat standard parallel (degrees), the circle of tangency.
00166      * @param[in] k0 scale on standard parallel.
00167      *
00168      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat
00169      * is not in the range [-90, 90].
00170      **********************************************************************/
00171     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r, real stdlat, real k0);
00172 
00173     /**
00174      * Constructor with two standard parallels.
00175      *
00176      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00177      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00178      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00179      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00180      * @param[in] stdlat1 first standard parallel (degrees).
00181      * @param[in] stdlat2 second standard parallel (degrees).
00182      * @param[in] k1 scale on the standard parallels.
00183      *
00184      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat1
00185      * or \e stdlat2 is not in the range [-90, 90].  In addition, if either \e
00186      * stdlat1 or \e stdlat2 is a pole, then an exception is thrown if \e
00187      * stdlat1 is not equal \e stdlat2
00188      **********************************************************************/
00189     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r, real stdlat1, real stdlat2, real k1);
00190 
00191     /**
00192      * Constructor with two standard parallels specified by sines and cosines.
00193      *
00194      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00195      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00196      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00197      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00198      * @param[in] sinlat1 sine of first standard parallel.
00199      * @param[in] coslat1 cosine of first standard parallel.
00200      * @param[in] sinlat2 sine of second standard parallel.
00201      * @param[in] coslat2 cosine of second standard parallel.
00202      * @param[in] k1 scale on the standard parallels.
00203      *
00204      * This allows parallels close to the poles to be specified accurately.
00205      * This routine computes the latitude of origin and the scale at this
00206      * latitude.  In the case where \e lat1 and \e lat2 are different, the
00207      * errors in this routines are as follows: if abs(\e lat2 - \e lat1) <=
00208      * 160<sup>o</sup> and max(abs(\e lat1), abs(\e lat2)) <=
00209      * 89.9999<sup>o</sup>, then the error in the latitude of origin is less
00210      * than 4e-14d and the relative error in the scale is less than 7e-15.
00211      **********************************************************************/
00212     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r,
00213                           real sinlat1, real coslat1,
00214                           real sinlat2, real coslat2,
00215                           real k1);
00216 
00217     /**
00218      * Set the scale for the projection.
00219      *
00220      * @param[in] lat (degrees).
00221      * @param[in] k scale at latitude \e lat (default 1).
00222      *
00223      * This allows a "latitude of true scale" to be specified.  An exception is
00224      * thrown if \e k is not positive.
00225      **********************************************************************/
00226     void SetScale(real lat, real k = real(1));
00227 
00228     /**
00229      * Forward projection, from geographic to Lambert conformal conic.
00230      *
00231      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00232      * @param[in] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00233      * @param[in] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00234      * @param[out] x easting of point (meters).
00235      * @param[out] y northing of point (meters).
00236      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00237      * @param[out] k scale of projection at point.
00238      *
00239      * The latitude origin is given by LambertConformalConic::LatitudeOrigin().
00240      * No false easting or northing is added and \e lat should be in the range
00241      * [-90, 90]; \e lon and \e lon0 should be in the range [-180, 360].  The
00242      * error in the projection is less than about 10 nm (true distance) and the
00243      * errors in the meridian convergence and scale are consistent with this.
00244      * The values of \e x and \e y returned for points which project to
00245      * infinity (i.e., one or both of the poles) will be large but finite.
00246      **********************************************************************/
00247     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00248                  real& x, real& y, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00249 
00250     /**
00251      * Reverse projection, from Lambert conformal conic to geographic.
00252      *
00253      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00254      * @param[in] x easting of point (meters).
00255      * @param[in] y northing of point (meters).
00256      * @param[out] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00257      * @param[out] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00258      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00259      * @param[out] k scale of projection at point.
00260      *
00261      * The latitude origin is given by LambertConformalConic::LatitudeOrigin().
00262      * No false easting or northing is added.  \e lon0 should be in the range
00263      * [-180, 360].  The value of \e lon returned is in the range [-180, 180).
00264      * The error in the projection is less than about 10 nm (true distance) and
00265      * the errors in the meridian convergence and scale are consistent with
00266      * this.
00267      **********************************************************************/
00268     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00269                  real& lat, real& lon, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00270 
00271     /**
00272      * LambertConformalConic::Forward without returning the convergence and
00273      * scale.
00274      **********************************************************************/
00275     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00276                  real& x, real& y) const throw() {
00277       real gamma, k;
00278       Forward(lon0, lat, lon, x, y, gamma, k);
00279     }
00280 
00281     /**
00282      * LambertConformalConic::Reverse without returning the convergence and
00283      * scale.
00284      **********************************************************************/
00285     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00286                  real& lat, real& lon) const throw() {
00287       real gamma, k;
00288       Reverse(lon0, x, y, lat, lon, gamma, k);
00289     }
00290 
00291     /** \name Inspector functions
00292      **********************************************************************/
00293     ///@{
00294     /**
00295      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00296      *   the value used in the constructor.
00297      **********************************************************************/
00298     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00299 
00300     /**
00301      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00302      *   value used in the constructor.  A value of 0 is returned for a sphere
00303      *   (infinite inverse flattening).
00304      **********************************************************************/
00305     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return _r; }
00306 
00307     /**
00308      * @return latitude of the origin for the projection (degrees).
00309      *
00310      * This is the latitude of minimum scale and equals the \e stdlat in the
00311      * 1-parallel constructor and lies between \e stdlat1 and \e stdlat2 in the
00312      * 2-parallel constructors.
00313      **********************************************************************/
00314     Math::real OriginLatitude() const throw() { return _lat0; }
00315 
00316     /**
00317      * @return central scale for the projection.  This is the scale on the
00318      *   latitude of origin..
00319      **********************************************************************/
00320     Math::real CentralScale() const throw() { return _k0; }
00321     ///@}
00322 
00323     /**
00324      * A global instantiation of LambertConformalConic with the WGS84 ellipsoid
00325      * and the UPS scale factor and \e stdlat = 0.  This degenerates to the
00326      * Mercator projection.
00327      **********************************************************************/
00328     static const LambertConformalConic Mercator;
00329   };
